content: the smell of iron fills the air and there's no question where it originates
in the center of this room is a massive fountain but instead of water it drips
with thick coagulating blood familiar horrors of teeth and guts rise up from
the dark red pool their door covered tentacles grip around you as a robed
figure laughs with glee hey guys welcome back to black magic crafts Halloween is
almost here in fact this is the last billed episode before All Hallows Eve is
upon us so I figured had to make something properly sinister I also
thought it would be really fun to challenge myself with the same criteria
for the October guild build crafts off I pulled out my collection of cheap
plastic Halloween skull decorations and got to work building something properly
sinister let's take a look at what I came up with at the beginning of this
project I really wasn't sure what I was gonna make the only thing that I knew is
that it would use some Halloween skulls I started digging through my collection
of bits looking for inspiration I decided that I wanted to use one of the
larger skulls to create some sort of an evil statue or set piece and quickly
thought it would be cool to create some kind of gory blood fountain I wanted the
mouth of the skull to be spewing blood that was important
luckily these particular skulls were a thin hollow plastic so it was easy to
cut between the teeth and allow the jaw to open had some foam bricks left over
from a previous project but I needed a base to build on I set to work milling
up some XPS foam into a square that I felt would be the appropriate size for a
pool I didn't measure this out it was just eyeballed then it was just a matter
of gluing some foam bricks around the perimeter of the base
I used Eileen's tacky glue for this it sets up fairly fast and doesn't create a
mess wisps like hot glue does when building
with little foam bricks I wanted the wall of the fountain to be two bricks
thick and once it came to laying the inner Rose I encountered my first
problem I had randomly picked the thickness of my square base and this
meant that my inner row of bricks would be sitting at a different height than
the outer ones this was an easy fix though I just cut another layer of base
to the appropriate thickness to bring it flush with the outside bricks after that
I could layout both rows until I got the height I wanted I wanted the big skull
to be seated on a bit of a pedestal so using some more bricks I created a small
step area within the pool for it to sit on I also thought I'd want a few smaller
skulls to adorn the corners of the fountain so I grabbed some smaller skull
beads and used some plastic arrows to fill the holes these would create
cool-looking spikes unfortunately I had a bit of a superglue mishap and
accidentally squirted superglue all over myself that really upsides
i primed the skull separately from the styrofoam so I could spray them out with
an aerosol primer with these sort of cheap plastic items it's a bit of a
crapshoot as to what will stick and in general a flat black spray-paint will
work best the foam itself however I covered in my usual Blackmagic craft
base coat which is just Mod Podge mixed with black craft paint one good thing
about the winter approaching is that the baseboard heaters in the game rooms
start being used so it creates a great little area to speed up drying time on
projects I painted the stone on the fountain using the same advanced stone
painting technique I outlined in episode 109 the only difference is that I also
put a coat of a deep red on the bottom of the pool to act as an undercoat of
color for when I later put on the somewhat translucent Blood effect the
skulls I painted out using the same method I demonstrated last week in
episode 112 I thought the bronze color and patina
would create a nice visual contrast to the blood red rather than just painting
them out in a boring stone one very important step in this project
is that I sprayed on my matte varnish to the items before doing the blood effects
I obviously wanted the blood to stay shiny and wet looking and if I were to
seal this piece when it was finished the matte varnish would dull the gloss of
the blood and make it look well terrible so this was my last chance to get on my
protective coating after that I attached the big skull to
the base with hot glue originally I thought I'd put one small skull on each
corner but I decided at the last minute it would look cooler to just have two
submerged skulls right in the blood pool for the blood I used my favorite
material for small liquid effects five minute epoxy I'm lucky that I can buy
this stuff at my local dollar store for a buck fifty a tube which makes it a
crazy cheap resin substitute even if you can't find it at your dollar store
buying it for a few bucks more at a place like Home Depot or Amazon is still
a really cost-effective option for small water effects buying actual two-part
resin can be expensive and it also has a low shelf life once opened resins begin
to fail after a few weeks or months depending on the brand so buying big
bottles for small pores can result in wasted material the other issue is
curing time some liquid resins take several hours or days to cure this 5
minute epoxy really only takes 5 to 10 minutes to set up and it never ever
seems to fail no matter what you mix into it in this case I mixed in a tiny
bit of Vallejo gory red the downside to this stuff is that it's very thick and
doesn't flow easily you also have a very short amount of working time it is
possible to thin it with acetone but I'm always hesitant to do so on foam crafts
just in case it causes some melting to deal with the low working time and
thickness I did two separate pours here building up the pool in layers as the
epoxy started to set up I created some trips from the skulls eyes and mouth to
really amp up the effect
I'm really happy with how this bill
turned out it combined a bunch of techniques I've recently covered on the
channel it used the October guild build
challenge material and it left me with a piece that was properly evil just in
time for Halloween if you want to pick up any supplies for this or other builds
head over to black magic craft CA where I have my essential equipment store
those links are Amazon affiliate links and shopping with them helps fund these
videos if you love these videos I make and you want to help me keep making them
the best way you can do that is by supporting black magic crafts on patreon
those funds ensure I can dedicate so much time and effort into these videos
each and every week oh and also you can help me out by
purchasing one of the cool new shirts I have available if you're into that sort
of thing links will be in the video description
below blood for the blood god there you have it guys I hope you found this video
enjoyable entertaining and most of all inspiring you did hit that like button
and let me know in the comments section below I hope you all have a amazing and
awesome safe Halloween Cheers
happy crafting
